intro: Pomazota assimilis, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mallow, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its stems are covered in fine, soft hairs. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. The flowers bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
